page.title: 17ELVERING ON THE SEVERN
page.content: FISHING BECOMES BIG BUSINESS From March to May young eels, known as elvers, make their way up the River Severn in their thousands. Fishermen, usually working at night, use boats equipped with lights and long nets to catch the elvers. They are then taken live to special elver stations in Gloucester or Epney, stored in large tanks and exported by air or road to the continent where they are considered to be a delicacy. Ten years ago there was only a local demand for elvers, indeed fried elver & bacon omelette was a favourite dish. Sandhurst residents could buy them for 65p/lb from fishermen. Now it is big business and local landowners complain of tresspassers and poachers crossing their fields with vans to catch elvers. Elver stations now pay up to 250p/lb for the live fish.
